text: hello this is Bill Cunningham reporting
on the end of New York Fashion Week and
the big party of the week the only party
I would say was not the after party but
the fashion presentations themselves
it seemed to me this year it was less
about celebrities and people were
focused on the creative presentations
and clothes by the designers the most
interesting thing I saw were a number of
important designers imposing a shape on
the woman other than her own it's been
done before but we haven't seen it
really since the 1950s valancy agha
here you have Proenza Schouler and all
their jackets and coats took a whole new
form of arch sleeves and shoulders and
Marc Jacobs who created a similar
silhouette in fur and in the work of Tom
Brown in here the art students from San
Francisco a group show of seven of them
and all of the shoulders and sleeves
reminded me of what we saw in the 1970s
in Paris other things that were
interesting was Donna Karan's a
celebration of the woman's body oh it
was definitely beautiful Michael Kors
turning from rather stiff narrow
silhouettes to a fluidity through the
cut of rather gossamer fabrics was a big
change for him another trend at night
that was amazing was the shearling coat
with the fur on the outside fee for
decades would everyone's been doing it
with the leather on the outside but this
design is from Phillip Lim and many
designers ended their presentation
with the splendor of gold Tom Brown it
remind you of a great pageant in Rome at
the Vatican and Diane Von Furstenburg
was an exuberant gold ending of 16
dresses and you just made you want to
run out in dance and his mouth was and
there were so many other things in the
shows these are just a few highlights
all of the collections are filled with
the artistry and work of these designers
there was no question that this was the
party of the week and it was about the
clothes not some silly after-party with
drinks
